author: Mark Sweney
title: Broadband users could see bills slashed as watchdog forces BT cut
text:
Broadband Broadband users could see bills slashed as BT is forced to cut charges 
Cost of superfast broadband could fall as Ofcom says Openreach should cut the wholesale prices it charges rival providers Ofcom wants BT’s Openreach to cut wholesale prices for superfast broadband. Photograph: Lynne Cameron/PA Broadband Broadband users could see bills slashed as BT is forced to cut charges 
Cost of superfast broadband could fall as Ofcom says Openreach should cut the wholesale prices it charges rival providers   08.46   08.51 BST 
Millions of broadband customers could see their bills slashed under proposals from Ofcom that would force BT to slash almost £100m in charges to rivals to provide services to their customers on its network. 
The telecoms watchdog has published proposals that would see BT-owned Openreach, which controls the UK’s broadband network, dramatically cut what it charges rivals such as Sky and TalkTalk to offer superfast 40Mb broadband packages to customers via its network. 
Currently Openreach charges rivals £88.80 a year in wholesale charges for each individual superfast package, one of the most popular with UK broadband users. Ofcom has launched a consultation to slash this by 40% to £52.77 a year by 2020/21. Broadband users in line for millions in Ofcom compensation plan Read more 
There are estimated to be between 2.4 million and 3 million non-BT customers currently taking the 40Mb package via Openreach, meaning the company’s fees will fall by close to £100m based on estimated customer levels. 
“We would expect these savings to be passed on to residential customers through cheaper prices,” said Ofcom. “This promotes competition in the superfast broadband service most used today by consumers.” 
Ofcom said that it intends to continue to allow Openreach to set its own wholesale pricing for the fastest broadband speed packages. 
It hopes that this cap on what Openreach is allowed to charge at the 40Mb speed will be enough of an incentive to encourage investment from BT and rivals in focussing on building ultrafast and full-fibre networks. 
“Ofcom wants to provide incentives to invest in ultrafast networks, while promoting competition and protecting consumers from high prices,” said Jonathan Oxley, competition group director at Ofcom. 
“People need reliable phone and broadband services more than ever. We’re making sure the market is delivering the best possible services for homes and business across the UK.” Topics
